trans-unit.source: Easy application installation and management in Azure Batch | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Easy application installation and management in Azure Batch | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Use the application packages feature of Azure Batch to easily manage multiple applications and versions for installation on Batch compute nodes.
trans-unit.target: Use the application packages feature of Azure Batch to easily manage multiple applications and versions for installation on Batch compute nodes.

trans-unit.source: Application deployment with Azure Batch application packages
trans-unit.target: Application deployment with Azure Batch application packages

trans-unit.source: The application packages feature of Azure Batch provides easy management and deployment of applications to the compute nodes in your pool.
trans-unit.target: The application packages feature of Azure Batch provides easy management and deployment of applications to the compute nodes in your pool.

trans-unit.source: With application packages, you can upload and manage multiple versions of the applications run by your tasks, including binaries and supporting files, then automatically deploy one or more of these applications to the compute nodes in your pool.
trans-unit.target: With application packages, you can upload and manage multiple versions of the applications run by your tasks, including binaries and supporting files, then automatically deploy one or more of these applications to the compute nodes in your pool.

trans-unit.source: In this article, you will learn how to upload and manage application packages using the Azure portal, then install them on a pool's compute nodes using the [Batch .NET][api_net] library.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you will learn how to upload and manage application packages using the Azure portal, then install them on a pool's compute nodes using the [Batch .NET][api_net] library.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The application packages feature described here supersedes the "Batch Apps" feature available in previous versions of the service.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The application packages feature described here supersedes the "Batch Apps" feature available in previous versions of the service.

trans-unit.source: Application packages requirements
trans-unit.target: Application packages requirements

trans-unit.source: The application packages feature discussed in this article is compatible *only* with Batch pools created after 10 March 2016.
trans-unit.target: The application packages feature discussed in this article is compatible *only* with Batch pools created after 10 March 2016.

trans-unit.source: Application packages will not be deployed to compute nodes in pools created before this date.
trans-unit.target: Application packages will not be deployed to compute nodes in pools created before this date.

trans-unit.source: This feature was introduced in [Batch REST API][api_rest] version 2015-12-01.2.2, and the corresponding [Batch .NET][api_net] library version 3.1.0.
trans-unit.target: This feature was introduced in [Batch REST API][api_rest] version 2015-12-01.2.2, and the corresponding [Batch .NET][api_net] library version 3.1.0.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you always use the latest API version when working with Batch.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you always use the latest API version when working with Batch.

trans-unit.source: About applications and application packages
trans-unit.target: About applications and application packages

trans-unit.source: Within Azure Batch, an **application** refers to a set of versioned binaries that can be automatically downloaded to the compute nodes in your pool.
trans-unit.target: Within Azure Batch, an **application** refers to a set of versioned binaries that can be automatically downloaded to the compute nodes in your pool.

trans-unit.source: An **application package** refers to a *specific set* of those binaries, and represents a given *version* of the application.
trans-unit.target: An **application package** refers to a *specific set* of those binaries, and represents a given *version* of the application.

trans-unit.source: High-level diagram of applications and application packages
trans-unit.target: High-level diagram of applications and application packages

trans-unit.source: Applications
trans-unit.target: Applications

trans-unit.source: An application in Batch contains one or more application packages.
trans-unit.target: An application in Batch contains one or more application packages.

trans-unit.source: It specifies configuration options for the application such as the default application package version to install on compute nodes, and whether its packages may be updated or deleted.
trans-unit.target: It specifies configuration options for the application such as the default application package version to install on compute nodes, and whether its packages may be updated or deleted.

trans-unit.source: Application packages
trans-unit.target: Application packages

trans-unit.source: An application package is a ZIP file containing the application binaries and supporting files required for execution by your tasks.
trans-unit.target: An application package is a ZIP file containing the application binaries and supporting files required for execution by your tasks.

trans-unit.source: Each application package represents a specific version of the application.
trans-unit.target: Each application package represents a specific version of the application.

trans-unit.source: When you create a pool in the Batch service, you can specify one or more of these applications and (optionally) a version, and those application packages will be downloaded automatically and extracted onto each node as it joins the pool.
trans-unit.target: When you create a pool in the Batch service, you can specify one or more of these applications and (optionally) a version, and those application packages will be downloaded automatically and extracted onto each node as it joins the pool.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] There are restrictions on the number of applications and application packages within a Batch account, as well as the maximum application package size.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] There are restrictions on the number of applications and application packages within a Batch account, as well as the maximum application package size.

trans-unit.source: See [Quotas and limits for the Azure Batch service](batch-quota-limit.md) for details on these limits.
trans-unit.target: See [Quotas and limits for the Azure Batch service](batch-quota-limit.md) for details on these limits.

trans-unit.source: Benefits of application packages
trans-unit.target: Benefits of application packages

trans-unit.source: Application packages can simplify the code in your Batch solution, as well as lower the overhead required in managing the applications your tasks run.
trans-unit.target: Application packages can simplify the code in your Batch solution, as well as lower the overhead required in managing the applications your tasks run.

trans-unit.source: With application packages, your pool's start task doesn't have to specify a long list of individual resource files to install on the nodes.
trans-unit.target: With application packages, your pool's start task doesn't have to specify a long list of individual resource files to install on the nodes.

trans-unit.source: You don't have to manually manage multiple versions of these files in Azure Storage, or on your nodes.
trans-unit.target: You don't have to manually manage multiple versions of these files in Azure Storage, or on your nodes.

trans-unit.source: And, you don't need to worry about generating [SAS URLs](../storage/storage-dotnet-shared-access-signature-part-1.md) to provide access to the files in your Azure Storage account.
trans-unit.target: And, you don't need to worry about generating [SAS URLs](../storage/storage-dotnet-shared-access-signature-part-1.md) to provide access to the files in your Azure Storage account.

trans-unit.source: Batch handles the details of working with Azure Storage in the background to store and deploy application packages to compute nodes, so both your code and your management overhead can be simplified.
trans-unit.target: Batch handles the details of working with Azure Storage in the background to store and deploy application packages to compute nodes, so both your code and your management overhead can be simplified.

trans-unit.source: Upload and manage applications
trans-unit.target: Upload and manage applications

trans-unit.source: Using the Azure portal, you can add, update, and delete application packages, and configure default versions for each application.
trans-unit.target: Using the Azure portal, you can add, update, and delete application packages, and configure default versions for each application.

trans-unit.source: At this time, these operations are supported only in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: At this time, these operations are supported only in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: In the next few sections, we'll first cover associating a Storage account with your Batch account, then review the package management features available in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: In the next few sections, we'll first cover associating a Storage account with your Batch account, then review the package management features available in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: After that, you'll learn how to deploy these packages to compute nodes using the [Batch .NET][api_net] library.
trans-unit.target: After that, you'll learn how to deploy these packages to compute nodes using the [Batch .NET][api_net] library.

trans-unit.source: Link a Storage account
trans-unit.target: Link a Storage account

trans-unit.source: In order to use application packages, you must first link an Azure Storage account to your Batch account.
trans-unit.target: In order to use application packages, you must first link an Azure Storage account to your Batch account.

trans-unit.source: If you have not yet configured a Storage account for your Batch account, the Azure portal will display a warning the first time you click the *Applications* tile in the Batch account blade.
trans-unit.target: If you have not yet configured a Storage account for your Batch account, the Azure portal will display a warning the first time you click the *Applications* tile in the Batch account blade.

trans-unit.source: No storage account configured warning in Azure portal
trans-unit.target: No storage account configured warning in Azure portal

trans-unit.source: The Batch service uses the associated Storage account for the storage and retrieval of application packages.
trans-unit.target: The Batch service uses the associated Storage account for the storage and retrieval of application packages.

trans-unit.source: Once you've linked the two accounts, Batch can automatically deploy the packages stored in the linked Storage account to your compute nodes.
trans-unit.target: Once you've linked the two accounts, Batch can automatically deploy the packages stored in the linked Storage account to your compute nodes.

trans-unit.source: Click **Storage account settings** on the *Warning* blade, then **Storage Account** on the *Storage Account* blade to link a storage account to your Batch account.
trans-unit.target: Click **Storage account settings** on the *Warning* blade, then **Storage Account** on the *Storage Account* blade to link a storage account to your Batch account.

trans-unit.source: Choose storage account blade in Azure portal
trans-unit.target: Choose storage account blade in Azure portal

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you create a storage account *specifically* for use with your Batch account, and select it here.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you create a storage account *specifically* for use with your Batch account, and select it here.

trans-unit.source: For details on creating a storage account, see "Create a storage account" in [About Azure storage accounts](../storage/storage-create-storage-account.md).
trans-unit.target: For details on creating a storage account, see "Create a storage account" in [About Azure storage accounts](../storage/storage-create-storage-account.md).

trans-unit.source: Once you've created a Storage account, you may then link it to your Batch account using the *Storage Account* blade.
trans-unit.target: Once you've created a Storage account, you may then link it to your Batch account using the *Storage Account* blade.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.WARNING] Because Batch stores your application packages using Azure Storage, you are [charged as normal][storage_pricing] for the block blob data.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.WARNING] Because Batch stores your application packages using Azure Storage, you are [charged as normal][storage_pricing] for the block blob data.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to consider the size and number of your application packages, and periodically remove deprecated packages to minimize cost.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to consider the size and number of your application packages, and periodically remove deprecated packages to minimize cost.

trans-unit.source: View current applications
trans-unit.target: View current applications

trans-unit.source: To view the applications in your Batch account, click the **Applications** tile in the Batch account blade.
trans-unit.target: To view the applications in your Batch account, click the **Applications** tile in the Batch account blade.

trans-unit.source: Applications tile
trans-unit.target: Applications tile

trans-unit.source: This opens the *Applications* blade:
trans-unit.target: This opens the *Applications* blade:

trans-unit.source: List applications
trans-unit.target: List applications

trans-unit.source: The *Applications* blade displays the ID of each application in your account, as well as the following properties:
trans-unit.target: The *Applications* blade displays the ID of each application in your account, as well as the following properties:

trans-unit.source: **Packages** - The number of versions associated with this application.
trans-unit.target: **Packages** - The number of versions associated with this application.

trans-unit.source: **Default version** – If you do not specify a version when setting the application for a pool, this version will be installed.
trans-unit.target: **Default version** – If you do not specify a version when setting the application for a pool, this version will be installed.

trans-unit.source: This setting is optional.
trans-unit.target: This setting is optional.

trans-unit.source: **Allow updates** – If this is set to *No*, package updates and deletions are disabled for the application--only new application package versions can be added.
trans-unit.target: **Allow updates** – If this is set to *No*, package updates and deletions are disabled for the application--only new application package versions can be added.

trans-unit.source: The default is *Yes*.
trans-unit.target: The default is *Yes*.

trans-unit.source: View application details
trans-unit.target: View application details

trans-unit.source: Clicking on an application in the *Applications* blade displays the details blade for that application.
trans-unit.target: Clicking on an application in the *Applications* blade displays the details blade for that application.

trans-unit.source: Application details
trans-unit.target: Application details

trans-unit.source: In the application details blade, you can configure the following settings for your application.
trans-unit.target: In the application details blade, you can configure the following settings for your application.

trans-unit.source: **Allow updates** - Specify whether its application packages can be updated or deleted (see "Update or Delete an application package" below).
trans-unit.target: **Allow updates** - Specify whether its application packages can be updated or deleted (see "Update or Delete an application package" below).

trans-unit.source: **Default version** - Specify a default application package to deploy to compute nodes.
trans-unit.target: **Default version** - Specify a default application package to deploy to compute nodes.

trans-unit.source: **Display name** - This is a "friendly" name that your Batch solution can use when displaying information about the application, such as in the UI of a service you provide your customers through Batch.
trans-unit.target: **Display name** - This is a "friendly" name that your Batch solution can use when displaying information about the application, such as in the UI of a service you provide your customers through Batch.

trans-unit.source: Add a new application
trans-unit.target: Add a new application

trans-unit.source: To create a new application, add an application package using a new, unique application id.
trans-unit.target: To create a new application, add an application package using a new, unique application id.

trans-unit.source: The first application package that you add using the new application id will also create the new application.
trans-unit.target: The first application package that you add using the new application id will also create the new application.

trans-unit.source: Click **Add** on the *Applications* blade to open the *New application* blade.
trans-unit.target: Click **Add** on the *Applications* blade to open the *New application* blade.

trans-unit.source: New application blade in Azure portal
trans-unit.target: New application blade in Azure portal

trans-unit.source: The *New application* blade provides the following fields for specifying the settings of your new application and application package.
trans-unit.target: The *New application* blade provides the following fields for specifying the settings of your new application and application package.

trans-unit.source: Metadata
trans-unit.target: Metadata

trans-unit.source: You can either supply the application metadata manually by entering values directly into the **Application id** and **Version** text boxes, or you can upload a JSON file that contains this metadata.
trans-unit.target: You can either supply the application metadata manually by entering values directly into the **Application id** and **Version** text boxes, or you can upload a JSON file that contains this metadata.

trans-unit.source: To specify the application id and version manually, simply leave the **Metadata** drop-down selector on **Enter metadata** (the default), and manually enter the values into the **Application id** and **Version** text boxes.
trans-unit.target: To specify the application id and version manually, simply leave the **Metadata** drop-down selector on **Enter metadata** (the default), and manually enter the values into the **Application id** and **Version** text boxes.

trans-unit.source: To specify a JSON-formatted metadata file containing the id and version for a package, select **Upload metatdata file** from the **Metadata** drop-down:
trans-unit.target: To specify a JSON-formatted metadata file containing the id and version for a package, select **Upload metatdata file** from the **Metadata** drop-down:

trans-unit.source: Upload metadata file drop-down selector
trans-unit.target: Upload metadata file drop-down selector

trans-unit.source: Then, click the folder icon next to the **Metadata file** text box that appears, and browse to the local file containing the JSON data.
trans-unit.target: Then, click the folder icon next to the **Metadata file** text box that appears, and browse to the local file containing the JSON data.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the file `litware_1.1001.2b.json` has been selected for upload, and the **Application id** and **Version** text boxes have been automatically populated with the information in the file:
trans-unit.target: In this example, the file `litware_1.1001.2b.json` has been selected for upload, and the **Application id** and **Version** text boxes have been automatically populated with the information in the file:

trans-unit.source: Metadata file selection detail
trans-unit.target: Metadata file selection detail

trans-unit.source: Use the following JSON format to specify the application package metadata in a file:
trans-unit.target: Use the following JSON format to specify the application package metadata in a file:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you upload a JSON metadata file for the id and version, you do *not* also need to edit the "Application id" or "Version" text boxes--they are automatically populated with the data in the JSON file.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you upload a JSON metadata file for the id and version, you do *not* also need to edit the "Application id" or "Version" text boxes--they are automatically populated with the data in the JSON file.

trans-unit.source: Application id
trans-unit.target: Application id

trans-unit.source: This specifies the id of your new application, which is subject to the standard Azure Batch ID validation rules:
trans-unit.target: This specifies the id of your new application, which is subject to the standard Azure Batch ID validation rules:

trans-unit.source: Can contain any combination of alphanumeric characters, including hyphens and underscores.
trans-unit.target: Can contain any combination of alphanumeric characters, including hyphens and underscores.

trans-unit.source: Cannot contain more than 64 characters.
trans-unit.target: Cannot contain more than 64 characters.

trans-unit.source: Must be unique within the Batch account.
trans-unit.target: Must be unique within the Batch account.

trans-unit.source: Case preserving, and case insensitive.
trans-unit.target: Case preserving, and case insensitive.

trans-unit.source: Version
trans-unit.target: Version

trans-unit.source: Specifies the version of the application package you are uploading.
trans-unit.target: Specifies the version of the application package you are uploading.

trans-unit.source: Version strings are subject to the following validation rules:
trans-unit.target: Version strings are subject to the following validation rules:

trans-unit.source: Can contain any combination of alphanumeric characters, including hyphens, underscores, and periods.
trans-unit.target: Can contain any combination of alphanumeric characters, including hyphens, underscores, and periods.

trans-unit.source: Cannot contain more than 64 characters.
trans-unit.target: Cannot contain more than 64 characters.

trans-unit.source: Must be unique within the application.
trans-unit.target: Must be unique within the application.

trans-unit.source: Case preserving, and case insensitive.
trans-unit.target: Case preserving, and case insensitive.

trans-unit.source: Application package
trans-unit.target: Application package

trans-unit.source: This specifies the ZIP file containing the application binaries and any supporting files required to execute the application.
trans-unit.target: This specifies the ZIP file containing the application binaries and any supporting files required to execute the application.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Select a file** text box or the folder icon to browse to and select a ZIP file containing your application's files.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Select a file** text box or the folder icon to browse to and select a ZIP file containing your application's files.

trans-unit.source: Once you've selected a file, click **OK** to begin the upload to Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Once you've selected a file, click **OK** to begin the upload to Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: When the upload operation completes, you will be notified and the blade will close.
trans-unit.target: When the upload operation completes, you will be notified and the blade will close.

trans-unit.source: Note that depending on the size of the file that you are uploading and the speed of your network connection, this operation may take some time.
trans-unit.target: Note that depending on the size of the file that you are uploading and the speed of your network connection, this operation may take some time.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.WARNING] Do not close the *New application* blade before the upload operation is complete.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.WARNING] Do not close the *New application* blade before the upload operation is complete.

trans-unit.source: Doing so will abort the upload process.
trans-unit.target: Doing so will abort the upload process.

trans-unit.source: Add a new application package
trans-unit.target: Add a new application package

trans-unit.source: To add a new application package version for an existing application, select an application in the *Applications* blade, click **Packages**, then click **Add** to display the *Add package* blade.
trans-unit.target: To add a new application package version for an existing application, select an application in the *Applications* blade, click **Packages**, then click **Add** to display the *Add package* blade.

trans-unit.source: Add application package blade in Azure portal
trans-unit.target: Add application package blade in Azure portal

trans-unit.source: As you can see, the fields match those of the *New application* blade, except for the disabled "Application id" text box.
trans-unit.target: As you can see, the fields match those of the *New application* blade, except for the disabled "Application id" text box.

trans-unit.source: As above, specify the **Version** for your new package, browse to your **Application package** ZIP file, then click **OK** to upload the package.
trans-unit.target: As above, specify the **Version** for your new package, browse to your **Application package** ZIP file, then click **OK** to upload the package.

trans-unit.source: Update or Delete an application package
trans-unit.target: Update or Delete an application package

trans-unit.source: To update or delete an existing application package, open the details blade for the application, click **Packages** to display the *Packages* blade, click the **ellipsis** in the row of the application package you wish to modify, and select the action you wish to perform.
trans-unit.target: To update or delete an existing application package, open the details blade for the application, click **Packages** to display the *Packages* blade, click the **ellipsis** in the row of the application package you wish to modify, and select the action you wish to perform.

trans-unit.source: Update or delete package in Azure portal
trans-unit.target: Update or delete package in Azure portal

trans-unit.source: Update
trans-unit.target: Update

trans-unit.source: When you click **Update**, the *Update package* blade is displayed.
trans-unit.target: When you click **Update**, the *Update package* blade is displayed.

trans-unit.source: This blade is similar to the *New application package* blade, however only the package selection field is enabled, allowing you to specify a new ZIP file to upload.
trans-unit.target: This blade is similar to the *New application package* blade, however only the package selection field is enabled, allowing you to specify a new ZIP file to upload.

trans-unit.source: Update package blade in Azure portal
trans-unit.target: Update package blade in Azure portal

trans-unit.source: Delete
trans-unit.target: Delete

trans-unit.source: When you click **Delete**, you are asked to confirm the deletion of the package version, and Batch deletes the package from Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: When you click **Delete**, you are asked to confirm the deletion of the package version, and Batch deletes the package from Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: If you delete the default version of an application, the default version setting is removed for the application.
trans-unit.target: If you delete the default version of an application, the default version setting is removed for the application.

trans-unit.source: Delete application
trans-unit.target: Delete application

trans-unit.source: Install applications on compute nodes
trans-unit.target: Install applications on compute nodes

trans-unit.source: Now that we've covered uploading and managing application packages using the Azure portal, we are ready to discuss actually deploying them to compute nodes and running them with Batch tasks.
trans-unit.target: Now that we've covered uploading and managing application packages using the Azure portal, we are ready to discuss actually deploying them to compute nodes and running them with Batch tasks.

trans-unit.source: To install an application package on the compute nodes in a pool, you specify one or more application package *references* for the pool.
trans-unit.target: To install an application package on the compute nodes in a pool, you specify one or more application package *references* for the pool.

trans-unit.source: In Batch .NET, you do so by adding one or more [CloudPool][net_cloudpool].[ApplicationPackageReferences][net_cloudpool_pkgref] when you create the pool, or to an existing pool.
trans-unit.target: In Batch .NET, you do so by adding one or more [CloudPool][net_cloudpool].[ApplicationPackageReferences][net_cloudpool_pkgref] when you create the pool, or to an existing pool.

trans-unit.source: The [ApplicationPackageReference][net_pkgref] class specifies an application ID and version to install on a pool's compute nodes.
trans-unit.target: The [ApplicationPackageReference][net_pkgref] class specifies an application ID and version to install on a pool's compute nodes.

trans-unit.source: Execute the installed applications
trans-unit.target: Execute the installed applications

trans-unit.source: As each compute node joins a pool (or is rebooted or reimaged) the packages you've specified are downloaded and extracted to a named directory within `AZ_BATCH_ROOT_DIR` on the node.
trans-unit.target: As each compute node joins a pool (or is rebooted or reimaged) the packages you've specified are downloaded and extracted to a named directory within `AZ_BATCH_ROOT_DIR` on the node.

trans-unit.source: Batch also creates an environment variable for your task command lines to use when calling the application binaries--this variable adheres to the following naming scheme:
trans-unit.target: Batch also creates an environment variable for your task command lines to use when calling the application binaries--this variable adheres to the following naming scheme:

trans-unit.source: For example, if you specify that version 2.7 of application *blender* be installed, your tasks can access its binaries by referencing the following environment variable in their command lines:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you specify that version 2.7 of application *blender* be installed, your tasks can access its binaries by referencing the following environment variable in their command lines:

trans-unit.source: If your application specifies a default version, you can reference the environment variable without the version string suffix.
trans-unit.target: If your application specifies a default version, you can reference the environment variable without the version string suffix.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you had specified default version 2.7 for the *blender* application within the Azure portal, your tasks can reference the following environment variable:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you had specified default version 2.7 for the *blender* application within the Azure portal, your tasks can reference the following environment variable:

trans-unit.source: The following code snippet shows how a task might be configured when a default version has been specified for the *blender* application.
trans-unit.target: The following code snippet shows how a task might be configured when a default version has been specified for the *blender* application.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] See "Environment settings for tasks" in the [Batch feature overview](batch-api-basics.md) for more information on compute node environment settings.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] See "Environment settings for tasks" in the [Batch feature overview](batch-api-basics.md) for more information on compute node environment settings.

trans-unit.source: Update a pool's application packages
trans-unit.target: Update a pool's application packages

trans-unit.source: If an existing pool has already been configured with an application package, you can specify a new package for the pool.
trans-unit.target: If an existing pool has already been configured with an application package, you can specify a new package for the pool.

trans-unit.source: All new nodes that join the pool will install the newly specified package, as will any existing node that is rebooted or reimaged.
trans-unit.target: All new nodes that join the pool will install the newly specified package, as will any existing node that is rebooted or reimaged.

trans-unit.source: Compute nodes that are already in the pool when you update the package references do not automatically install the new application package.
trans-unit.target: Compute nodes that are already in the pool when you update the package references do not automatically install the new application package.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the existing pool has version 2.7 of the *blender* application configured as one of its [CloudPool][net_cloudpool].[ApplicationPackageReferences][net_cloudpool_pkgref].
trans-unit.target: In this example, the existing pool has version 2.7 of the *blender* application configured as one of its [CloudPool][net_cloudpool].[ApplicationPackageReferences][net_cloudpool_pkgref].

trans-unit.source: To update the pool's nodes with version 2.76b, specify a new [ApplicationPackageReference][net_pkgref] with the new version, and commit the change.
trans-unit.target: To update the pool's nodes with version 2.76b, specify a new [ApplicationPackageReference][net_pkgref] with the new version, and commit the change.

trans-unit.source: Now that the new version has been configured, any *new* node joining the pool will have version 2.76b deployed to it.
trans-unit.target: Now that the new version has been configured, any *new* node joining the pool will have version 2.76b deployed to it.

trans-unit.source: To install 2.76b on the nodes that are *already* in the pool, reboot (or reimage) them.
trans-unit.target: To install 2.76b on the nodes that are *already* in the pool, reboot (or reimage) them.

trans-unit.source: Note that rebooted nodes will retain the files from previous package deployments.
trans-unit.target: Note that rebooted nodes will retain the files from previous package deployments.

trans-unit.source: List the applications in a Batch account
trans-unit.target: List the applications in a Batch account

trans-unit.source: You can list the applications and their packages in a Batch account by using the [ApplicationOperations][net_appops].[ListApplicationSummaries][net_appops_listappsummaries] method.
trans-unit.target: You can list the applications and their packages in a Batch account by using the [ApplicationOperations][net_appops].[ListApplicationSummaries][net_appops_listappsummaries] method.

trans-unit.source: Wrapping up
trans-unit.target: Wrapping up

trans-unit.source: With application packages, you can more easily provide your customers with the ability to select the applications for their jobs, and specify the exact version to use, when processing jobs with your Batch-enabled service.
trans-unit.target: With application packages, you can more easily provide your customers with the ability to select the applications for their jobs, and specify the exact version to use, when processing jobs with your Batch-enabled service.

trans-unit.source: You might also provide the ability for your customers to upload and track their own applications in your service.
trans-unit.target: You might also provide the ability for your customers to upload and track their own applications in your service.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: The [Batch REST API][api_rest] also provides support for working with application packages.
trans-unit.target: The [Batch REST API][api_rest] also provides support for working with application packages.

trans-unit.source: For example, see the [applicationPackageReferences][rest_add_pool_with_packages] element in [Add a pool to an account][rest_add_pool] for specifying packages to install using the REST API.
trans-unit.target: For example, see the [applicationPackageReferences][rest_add_pool_with_packages] element in [Add a pool to an account][rest_add_pool] for specifying packages to install using the REST API.

trans-unit.source: See [Applications][rest_applications] for details on obtaining application information using the Batch REST API.
trans-unit.target: See [Applications][rest_applications] for details on obtaining application information using the Batch REST API.

trans-unit.source: Learn how to programmatically [manage Azure Batch accounts and quotas with Batch Management .NET](batch-management-dotnet.md).
trans-unit.target: Learn how to programmatically [manage Azure Batch accounts and quotas with Batch Management .NET](batch-management-dotnet.md).

trans-unit.source: The [Batch Management .NET][api_net_mgmt] library can enable account creation and deletion features for your Batch application or service.
trans-unit.target: The [Batch Management .NET][api_net_mgmt] library can enable account creation and deletion features for your Batch application or service.
